Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level AL, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students use simple English words and phrases to communicate with teachers and peers in familiar routine situations.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They listen to others and concentrate for short periods.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They follow one- and 2-step instructions, exchange simple personal information and attempt to use the foundational oral English needed to manage learning in an English-speaking classroom.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They begin to adapt their emerging English language skills and knowledge to respond to new communicative and functional demands.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use simple, learnt formulaic responses to communicate.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Their utterances are characterised by a reliance on key vocabulary and/or paralinguistic (non-verbal) communication such as gestures, facial expressions and head movements with many home language influences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some basic communication and learning strategies to participate and/or repair miscommunication in English.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate familiarity with some basic patterns in the sounds, intonation, rhythm, grammar and meaning of English.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They attempt to copy pronunciation, stress and intonation used by others.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They repeat key words and phrases that others use.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use home language peers as supports for learning and use resources, including classroom print texts such as pictures, diagrams, posters and other visual texts, to help them communicate.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students show interest in a variety of English texts and concentrate for short periods of time when reading or viewing short texts in print or visual form.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate reading-like behaviours, including holding a book, looking at the cover and pages of a book, turning single pages and looking at pictures.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise basic features of English texts, including page order and the role of illustrations in texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They focus on images and other visual features that assist them to understand texts, and rely on peer or teacher support to complete simple structured activities such as sequencing pictures or acting out the key elements of a text.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They read some environmental print, including their name and other familiar words and signs.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise and name some familiar letters and know the sounds commonly related to some letters and letter groups.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: When listening to texts being read aloud, they identify key words, and repeated words and phrases.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They attempt to participate in shared reading experiences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate their ideas and experiences through drawings and attempts at writing copied from other sources such as environmental print and very short teacher-modelled texts, showing evidence of an emerging understanding of writing processes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate interest and some ability to concentrate in shared writing activities, including watching the teacher and other students writing.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They participate in shared writing experiences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate awareness that written texts in English are presented through conventions that change according to context and purpose.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use drawings to represent simple descriptions, recounts and procedures.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They copy words or phrases from books, vocabulary lists and other resources, and can write their own name.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They attempt to use different writing implements and learn how to hold and use them correctly.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate some understanding of the left-to-right directionality of English script and the importance of spacing and writing on lines.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate knowledge of some phoneme–grapheme correspondences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They talk about their pictures and copied writing using simple words and sentences that draw on their developing oral English language skills, and/or their home language(s), especially when sharing with home language peers or a multilingual teacher.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level A1, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate in simple English phrases and sentences in routine and familiar social and classroom situations.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They follow and give simple instructions, exchange personal information, and participate in familiar and predictable activities and contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They modify their responses and manner of interaction to match the responses of others and the context.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use learnt formulaic responses and patterns, and create original utterances by substituting words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Their utterances have a short, simplified structure with simple subject–verb–object construction and overgeneralisation of rules.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use basic communication and learning strategies to participate in and sustain interactions in English.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise that intonation carries meaning, and they identify key words and repeated words and phrases.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use comprehensible pronunciation, stress and intonation.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use classroom resources such as picture cards and other visual texts to aid communication.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read and engage with a wide range of short, simple, repetitive texts, including shared recounts and fictional and everyday texts, in print or visual form.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read, in context, some familiar words, phrases, numbers and signs.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They complete simple, structured activities such as sequencing sentences and pictures.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand that texts are written and structured for a variety of purposes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise some common letters and letter patterns.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They name some letters of the alphabet and know the sounds commonly related to some letters and letter groups.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise features of texts, including text directionality and page order, and understand the function of titles and images.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They hold and manipulate books appropriately.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: When listening to texts being read aloud, they listen for key words and for repetition of words and phrases.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They focus on images and other visual features that assist them to understand texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate their ideas and experiences through drawings, copied writing, dictated texts and their own writing, showing evidence of a developing understanding of the writing process.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They contribute to shared writing activities.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate awareness that written texts in English are presented through particular conventions, which change according to context and purpose.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write and draw for basic purposes and, with support, produce simple descriptions, recounts and procedural texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students’ writing reflects their spoken structures, and they link ideas using basic conjunctions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use basic punctuation in their writing.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate knowledge of some phoneme–grapheme correspondences when writing and spelling words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They show evidence of some basic planning for writing.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They model their writing on shared writing activities and published texts, often copying words or phrases from books or vocabulary lists.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They form letters and place text appropriately on a page.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use basic digital resources to write and present their texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level A2, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate in a range of predictable and familiar social and learning situations.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They express ideas and identify key points of information in classroom discussions about familiar topics, and about new topics when they are well supported by visual material, an appropriate pace of delivery, and discussion that links their prior knowledge to the new context.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They follow a short sequence of instructions related to classroom procedures and learning activities.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They negotiate familiar social and learning situations, using English appropriate to the situation.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They adjust their speech choices in response to audiences and topics.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They combine known conversational formulas and vocabulary, including some from texts read in class, and apply grammatical rules to make original utterances of varying grammatical accuracy.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They sustain communication by negotiating turn-taking and by using strategies such as asking a speaker to repeat or to speak slowly, or by asking what a word means.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read and respond to a wide range of familiar print or digital texts, including visual, multimodal and interactive texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They predict, ask questions, retell and talk about texts read and viewed in class.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With support, students read a range of topic-related classroom texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They can read familiar texts with some fluency.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They read back their own writing or their own sentences recorded by another student.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use texts purposefully, following simple procedural texts and finding basic information in texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They discuss the events and characters’ feelings and actions in texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They identify the purposes of familiar text types, including classroom text, simple story and factual text.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use their developing knowledge of context, phoneme–grapheme correspondences, word patterns and text structure to read simple texts, both familiar and unfamiliar.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They interpret simple images and identify the layout of a range of text types.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate ideas, events and experiences through simple texts based on familiar spoken and written language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write for a variety of personal and classroom purposes, using known and modelled structures and features.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write everyday texts and simple stories, recounts and factual texts based on their own and shared class experiences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use their developing oral and reading skills when writing their own texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write texts using simple but coherently linked sentences, basic structures and well-known vocabulary.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some common irregular past tense verbs correctly, and link clauses using basic conjunctions and connectives.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They make plausible attempts to spell unfamiliar words, based on known spelling patterns and base words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use vocabulary lists, modelled texts and familiar books to find out how to write unfamiliar words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write letters legibly, include some punctuation and make some changes to their texts when editing.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use digital resources to write and present their texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level BL, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate in familiar social and classroom contexts, using simple formulaic and some creative structures.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand spoken English that is supported by teacher direction and cues from classroom context.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They contribute relatively complex ideas through simple spoken English, and use simple English to respond to the ideas of others.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: This is achieved through continuing support and scaffolding from teachers and English-speaking peers who provide authentic interactions and space to practise English.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Peers who speak home language(s) also offer shared translation opportunities.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: This supports students to make connections between their home language(s) and their developing English language skills.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students use short utterances and simple subject–verb–object constructions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use common adjectives and adverbs to describe or add emphasis.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use repeated grammar patterns copied from stories, songs, rhymes or other short texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students’ pronunciation, stress and intonation are comprehensible but carry elements of home language pronunciation.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some basic communication strategies, such as asking for repetition, and by questioning to check, clarify or confirm understanding.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some basic strategies to initiate and sustain simple conversations in English, including restating, repeating or re-pronouncing as appropriate.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read a variety of short, simple, familiar, repetitive fiction and everyday texts in print and digital form, including visual, multimodal and interactive texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They complete basic structured activities for the texts they read.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students retell simple, familiar stories, and sequence a process using simple sentences and pictures.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand that texts are written for a variety of purposes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand the basic phoneme–grapheme correspondences of English.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read some familiar words and phrases in context.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise, name and know the sounds related to all letters and some common letter groups.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise that meaning is carried by intonation, and they listen for key words and for repetition of words and phrases in texts read aloud.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They focus on illustrations and other non-written features when reading.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use vocabulary lists and simple pictorial and bilingual dictionaries to assist them to read unfamiliar words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate their ideas and experiences simply through written, drawn, copied or dictated texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They contribute to whole-class or small-group shared writing activities.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand that written texts in English comprise specific conventions, which change according to context and purpose.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write simple sequenced descriptions, recounts and procedures, following models.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write or draw for specific audiences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students engage in a variety of writing activities where they develop ideas with peers, seek feedback from teachers and use model texts to inform their own writing.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students’ writing reflects the text structures and linguistic features of their spoken language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They link ideas using common conjunctions, and understand the purpose of basic punctuation and use it in their texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate knowledge of some English phoneme–grapheme correspondences and spelling of high-frequency words, and show evidence of some planning.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They model their writing on shared writing activities and published texts, and use some basic strategies, such as copying words or phrases from lists, using images and asking how to write a word.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They begin to form letters and place text appropriately.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They copy and write texts using digital tools.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level B1, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate verbally and non-verbally in routine and familiar social and classroom situations, supported by cues in the immediate context.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use formulas, well-rehearsed and common sentence patterns, and short, simple utterances to contribute relatively complex ideas, usually about concrete subject matter.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students follow simple instructions, answer predictable questions, make basic requests and express their needs using simple sentences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand that English changes according to context and audience, and they modify their use of English in response to a range of familiar classroom and social purposes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use appropriate social formulas and non-verbal language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Their utterances are characterised by varying grammatical accuracy.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use common adjectives and adverbs to describe or add emphasis.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use basic communication strategies, asking for repetition and questioning to clarify and confirm understanding.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They restate their ideas and repeat or re-pronounce key words when necessary.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read short, familiar print and digital texts, including visual, multimodal and interactive texts, that use simple language structures and features, common vocabulary and familiar contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They retell simple stories, predict likely outcomes, sequence ideas and complete basic comprehension activities.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students understand the basic purposes of texts and choose texts appropriate for their purpose.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With support, they read and gather basic information from simple, accessible texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: When reading, students combine their basic knowledge of English phoneme–grapheme correspondences, their developing spoken and sight vocabulary, their knowledge of the conventions of text organisation and their knowledge of English grammar.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use appropriate intonation and phrasing when reading aloud, showing an understanding of a text’s meaning and the function of basic punctuation.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate understanding of a narrow range of text organisational features including headings, labels, diagrams and contents pages.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students write and present simple texts for a variety of basic classroom and personal purposes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With support, they communicate familiar ideas, events and experiences, writing simple narratives, recounts, descriptions and reports.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some of the basic structures and features common to these text types, demonstrating a growing awareness that purpose influences the way texts are written and presented.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students’ written texts incorporate the basic grammatical features of their spoken English.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They spell some common and familiar words accurately and make plausible attempts to spell unfamiliar words using known English phoneme–grapheme correspondences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use simple strategies for spelling words, such as checking vocabulary lists or books.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With support, they plan and edit their texts, providing additional information through visual images.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use a range of digital tools to write and present their texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level B2, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate in English in predictable social and learning situations.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand some de-contextualised English and express simple messages in basic English.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They negotiate simple transactions and ask and answer simple questions on familiar topics, using familiar response structures.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students identify and describe people, places and things using simple vocabulary.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They describe a series of events or actions using some detail.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They initiate and manage interactions appropriately in a range of familiar contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand instructions, recounts and explanations when contextually supported.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use simple English with varying degrees of grammatical accuracy.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They combine known formulaic responses, learnt grammatical features and new vocabulary to construct new utterances.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use basic time and sequence markers, and simple negative forms.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use verb endings with some consistency.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some of the terminology of new topics in their utterances.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They pronounce familiar words comprehensibly.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They employ familiar strategies to sustain and enhance communication in English.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read familiar and unfamiliar print and digital texts, including visual, multimodal and interactive texts, that contain predictable structures and familiar vocabulary.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students follow simple written instructions and respond to simple written questions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They identify the main purposes of a range of texts and recognise the basic features of common text types.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use their developing vocabulary and their knowledge of sentence structure and English phoneme–grapheme correspondences to predict and self-correct.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They modify intonation to distinguish questions, exclamations and dialogueue when reading aloud.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They follow logical relationships between events and ideas expressed by common cohesive devices.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They sequence sentences from known texts or a text on a familiar topic or experience.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use simple strategies to assess text difficulty and to choose new texts to read.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students write for a range of purposes on familiar topics.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write simple, organised texts that demonstrate the use of specific vocabulary and simple sentence structures.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Their writing demonstrates their understanding of the purposes, structures and features of common text types.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students’ written texts include basic information and simple detail.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students use common conjunctions to link ideas, and use pronoun references with some noun–pronoun agreement.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use simple phrases to express basic comparisons, and use some basic punctuation with consistency.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They make plausible attempts to spell unfamiliar words using known English phoneme–grapheme correspondences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use a range of strategies for spelling words, including checking vocabulary lists and keeping a personal dictionary.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write new sentences using known sentence structures.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They draw on their knowledge of the writing process to plan and write simple texts and, with support, redraft them.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use a range of digital tools to write, edit and present their texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level B3, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students appropriately respond to and use the structures and features of spoken English in a variety of familiar formal and informal contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate awareness of the register requirements such as tone, formality of language, vocabulary and body language of spoken English that are used when speaking for different purposes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand the essential meaning of unfamiliar topics expressed in familiar spoken English, and extract specific information from spoken texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use appropriate sequence markers and consistently use the most common irregular past tenses.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They provide detail by using longer noun groups and adverbial phrases when speaking, and use comprehensible pronunciation, stress and intonation.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They access English from a variety of spoken and written sources, and extend their spoken skills by incorporating new vocabulary from these sources into their own repertoire.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They self-correct some errors, reformulate language to convey meaning more clearly, and add essential details.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read with increasing independence for a range of purposes, and identify the main ideas and specific information in classroom texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: These texts may be print or digital, including visual, multimodal and interactive texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students demonstrate understanding of the main storyline and most key information when retelling, paraphrasing and answering questions, and they compare details in texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate awareness of how information is organised in English texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise the cohesive devices that connect ideas and the organisation of information in a text.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use appropriate metalanguage to talk about the structure and features of a text.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise how relationships are signalled by an increasing range of conjunctions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They integrate a number of strategies to help them read unfamiliar texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use English dictionaries to check the meaning of unfamiliar words, and use contents pages, indexes, glossaries and headings to find information.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate for a range of purposes on a variety of topics, using a repertoire of familiar text types.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write sequenced and ordered information texts, and narrative texts that maintain a cohesive storyline and characterisation.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate an awareness of how effective writing is tailored to a purpose, the requirements of the topic and the needs of the reader.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They gather and present information appropriately in texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write texts that demonstrate overall cohesion and coherence.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students can combine and sequence simple sentences and paragraphs using common conjunctions and pronouns.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They generally maintain appropriate tense throughout their texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They discuss and reflect on their own writing, incorporating feedback when planning, reviewing or presenting their texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They revise texts during writing, and proofread them after a first draft has been written, improving spelling, punctuation and sentence structure.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They present their writing appropriately, in print and digital forms.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level CL, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate using simple spoken English in familiar, structured social and classroom contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use formulaic language; short, simple and well-rehearsed grammatical features; and adaptations of their emerging English repertoire.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use stress and intonation appropriately in some familiar interactions and can imitate model texts with some accuracy.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand common instructions and questions, and simple descriptions and explanations, when strongly supported in familiar contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand and use basic subject–verb–object grammatical patterns, common regular and irregular verbs, basic prepositions and connectives such as time and sequence markers.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They ask and respond to questions in predictable contexts, express simple ideas and preferences, and provide short explanations and descriptions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some strategies to initiate and sustain basic conversations in English, repeating and re-pronouncing as necessary.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read a wide range of simple, familiar fiction, information and everyday print and digital texts in handwritten, visual, multimodal and interactive formats.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They complete simple structured activities about these texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read their own writing and other simple texts based on well-rehearsed spoken English.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They name some letters and know the sounds related to many letters and common letter combinations.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They attempt to sound out words, recognise some high-frequency words and read some unfamiliar words based on the similarity of these to known words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate awareness of basic punctuation and use stress, intonation or pausing appropriately when reading familiar texts aloud.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use simple strategies such as pointing to words as they read, or as shared texts are read aloud in class.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand the basic practical and cultural purposes of the texts they read.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students write short, grammatically simple texts based on well-rehearsed spoken and well-practised written English in familiar contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write for a range of basic classroom and personal purposes, such as making lists and writing simple recounts and notes, and complete activities following models and examples.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They recognise that print texts in English are based on certain conventions, which change according to context and purpose.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Their texts use familiar sentence patterns from well-known texts or classroom models.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They begin to use conventional letter formations when writing or copying text, attending to the relative sizes and shapes of letters, their position on a line and basic punctuation.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They leave appropriate spaces between words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They attempt to write some unfamiliar words using their developing knowledge of phoneme–grapheme correspondences in English, referring to personal dictionaries, glossaries and classroom resources and asking for assistance.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They copy and create texts using digital tools.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level C1, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students communicate simply but effectively in English, in social and classroom contexts across the curriculum.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They negotiate meaning and interact with others using formulaic language; short, simple and well-rehearsed grammatical features; and creative adaptations of their English repertoire.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some stress and intonation appropriately in familiar interactions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use subject–verb–object utterances, basic prepositions and some common regular and irregular verbs.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand and use introduced vocabulary, common basic grammatical patterns and connectives such as time and sequence markers with varying grammatical accuracy to express ideas and preferences, and to provide simple explanations and descriptions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand simple instructions and questions, descriptions or explanations in familiar contexts and topics related to their prior knowledge and experience.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some basic strategies to initiate and sustain conversations, including repeating or re-pronouncing as necessary.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read and comprehend a range of short, simple, familiar information or fictional texts developed by the teacher.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: These texts may be print or digital, including handwritten, visual, multimodal and interactive texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students understand a range of basic print instructions and questions in context.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They discuss texts at a literal level and show some inferential understanding.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate an understanding of basic text structure, reading for different purposes, and they use titles and chapter headings to make predictions about texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They combine their developing knowledge of English phoneme–grapheme correspondences, their developing oral and sight vocabulary, their beginning knowledge of the conventions of print text organisation in English and their emerging knowledge of English grammar to read unfamiliar texts with support.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They read some common letter combinations and make logical attempts at reading unfamiliar words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use appropriate stress, intonation and phrasing when reading known texts aloud, showing an understanding of the function of basic punctuation.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students write for a range of basic classroom and personal purposes, including making lists and writing simple journal entries, notes, descriptions, recounts of events and instructional texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write simple sentences and short texts that are based on well-practised spoken English and familiar contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They write with varying grammatical accuracy, expressing themselves using familiar vocabulary and modelled structures and features.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They order and sequence sentences about familiar topics into simple coherent texts, incorporating basic conventions such as headings and paragraphs.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They correct some grammatical errors and rework drafts in response to the teacher’s suggestions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With support, they plan their texts and provide some additional information through visual texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use a range of strategies for finding and spelling words, using spelling patterns and checking resources.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use digital tools to write and present their texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level C2, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students use simple strategies for initiating communication and negotiating meaning.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They communicate effectively in a range of familiar social and some basic academic contexts, experimenting with and adapting their developing English and cultural understanding.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With support in academic contexts, they extract some specific information from texts and understand teacher explanations involving familiar, specific curriculum area vocabulary.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With support, they use some increasingly complex grammatical features, and a basic range of connectives such as time and sequence markers, to show relationships between ideas.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some conventional expressions to express views and attitudes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate some understanding of the structures and features of extended texts by using appropriate stress, intonation, pauses and eye contact, and modelled introductory and concluding sentences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students read and comprehend a range of short, familiar fictional and information print and digital texts and, when well supported, some unfamiliar texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: These texts include handwritten, visual, multimodal and interactive texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students demonstrate comprehension beyond the literal level, by suggesting appropriate interpretations and identifying basic cultural variables where evident.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use headings and diagrams to assist in reading texts from all the curriculum areas and for a range of purposes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They extract the main ideas from information texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They show awareness of how some connectives link and sequence ideas within a text.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They read and consider the context when deducing the meaning of unfamiliar words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They read aloud with a degree of fluency, and draw on their understanding of the text to use stress and intonation with increasing accuracy.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use their developing knowledge of sentence structure and phoneme–grapheme correspondences to read unfamiliar words and self-correct.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They select basic texts appropriate for specific reading purposes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students write for a range of everyday classroom and personal purposes, such as describing, explaining and recounting.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They independently write some basic texts and experiment with presenting their own ideas.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Their texts show varying spelling and grammatical accuracy.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They incorporate emerging vocabulary, punctuation and grammatical features to achieve desired effects.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use an increasing range of simple connectives to indicate basic relationships within and between sentences and paragraphs.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They choose appropriate text structures and use headings, tables and images.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use simple model texts as a basis for their own texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use strategies to organise information in supported research tasks.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With teacher support and feedback, they review, redraft and improve their writing by discussing alternative ways of arranging and expressing ideas.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use a range of digital resources to write, edit and publish their texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level C3, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students listen, question and respond successfully in a wide range of social and academic contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate sufficient control of stress, rhythm and intonation to be understood in most contexts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use appropriate non-verbal language, take account of purpose and audience, and structure extended texts appropriately when participating in group debates and discussions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They discuss texts from across the curriculum using modelled examples in supportive classroom situations and structured group work.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With varying accuracy, they use a range of question types, time signals, conjunctions and modal verbs to express points of view and to give and justify opinions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They interpret spoken and print texts and, with support, understand the full text.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They listen for specific information when questions are given beforehand.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand small amounts of abstract and generalised information when appropriate background is provided.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students demonstrate a basic understanding of the main ideas, issues or plot developments in a range of print and digital texts across all curriculum areas.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: These texts include handwritten, visual, multimodal and interactive texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students demonstrate a basic understanding of the different purposes and structures of a range of text types and can make predictions about the likely content of texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They identify the structure of imaginative texts they read, and the role of headings, diagrams and captions in information texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They follow meaning across sentences and paragraphs by tracking basic cohesive and reference items, and clearly expressed cues in sentence structure and vocabulary.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use appropriate metalanguage to talk about the structure and features of a text.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They adjust their rate of reading to a task, reading closely for analysis, scanning for specific information and skimming for the main idea.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use their knowledge of phoneme–grapheme correspondences and cues from surrounding text to assist in reading unfamiliar words.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: By the end of Level C4, students demonstrate the following skills in English as an Additional Language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students demonstrate greater autonomy and control over their use of English, combining their expanding vocabulary with the appropriate use of a wide range of complex grammatical features including modal verbs, passive voice and tenses.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate understanding of the ways in which pauses, stress, rhythm and intonation help to clarify meaning.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They speak clearly and pronounce most sounds correctly.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They take part in extended discourse on factual and interpersonal topics using an appropriate modelled structure, and respond appropriately to listeners’ reactions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They deliver formal and informal presentations to an audience.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They identify the intention of supportive speakers, using their knowledge of how intonation, volume, stress and lexical choices support and convey meaning and emphasise opinions and emotions.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They identify examples of relatively explicit subjective language.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They extract information from challenging spoken texts, using guide questions and taking notes on key ideas.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students compare and make judgements about different texts (such as texts on the same topic by different authors) and read a wide range of accessible and culturally appropriate texts from across the curriculum with a high degree of independence.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: These texts may be print or digital, including handwritten, visual, multimodal and interactive texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students take notes that identify main ideas, issues and plot developments.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They identify supporting information to justify a response, including significant quotations that relate to key themes.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They understand the main meaning by focusing on the first lines of key paragraphs.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They adjust their reading style to a task.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They locate and organise information from a range of reference sources, including the internet, and begin to synthesise and make meaning from increasingly complex texts.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They identify reference items across complex sentences.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They predict the way a text may be organised and its likely language features.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With more difficult texts, they identify a few specific facts and the basic perspective of the writer.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: Students write, with appropriate support, the full range of extended imaginative and information text types undertaken across the curriculum.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: With support, they vary their writing to be consistent with the text type, the context and the needs of the reader, presenting similar content in different ways.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They demonstrate reasonably consistent control of a wide range of grammatical features, including spelling.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They incorporate direct and indirect speech, including quotations, appropriately.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They employ an extended range of appropriate cohesive devices between sentences and paragraphs, retaining clarity and fluency.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They use some abstract noun groups.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: In response to feedback and self-assessment, they review and redraft their writing to enhance fluency, clarity, accuracy and appropriateness for purpose, audience and context.

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ASComponentText: They plan, draft, edit and present their writing in a range of print and digital forms, as appropriate.
